Book.description: Represents a book in the bookstore's inventory.

id.description: Unique identifier for the Book entity.

stockQuantity.description: The number of copies of the book in stock.

imageUrl.description: URL of the book's cover image.

Order.title: Order
Order.description: Represents an order placed by a user.

id.description: Unique identifier for the Order entity.

userId.description: The ID of the user who placed the order.

userName.description: The name of the user who placed the order.

userEmail.description: The email of the user who placed the order.

createdAt.description: The server timestamp when the order was created.

status.description: The status of the order (e.g., Pending, Shipped, Delivered).

paymentStatus.description: The payment status of the order.

items.description: An array of items included in the order.

totalPrice.description: The total price of the order.

User.title: User
User.description: Represents a user of the bookstore system.

id.description: Unique identifier for the User entity.

email.description: The email address of the user.

role.description: The role of the user (Customer or Admin).

imageUrl.description: URL of the book's cover image.

quantity.description: The quantity of the book in the cart.

firestore.reasoning:
The Firestore data structure is designed to support the BookVerse API's requirements for managing books, users, and orders while prioritizing security and scalability. It emphasizes authorization independence by avoiding hierarchical `get()` calls in security rules. This is achieved by denormalizing user roles and order ownership where necessary.

The structure is segregated to ensure that each collection has a homogeneous security posture.  Private user data is stored under the `/users/{userId}` path, enforcing path-based ownership for user-specific data. A user's shopping cart and orders are subcollections at `/users/{userId}/cart` and `/users/{userId}/orders`. Book data is stored in a top-level `/books` collection, which is accessible to both customers (read) and admins (CRUD). Admin order management is enabled by a top-level `/orders` collection containing denormalized order data. The admin role is managed via the `/roles_admin/{userId}` collection.

This design facilitates QAPs by:

*   Segregating data based on access control needs, enabling secure `list` operations for books available to all users.
*   Using the `/users/{userId}/cart` and `/users/{userId}/orders` paths, allowing secure listing of a user's own private items.
*   Allowing admins to list all orders from the top-level `/orders` collection.
*   Employing existence-based checks for admin roles within the `/roles_admin` collection, allowing secure checks without needing to read document data.

Denormalization Strategy: The primary denormalization involves copying book details into cart and order items. This ensures that order history remains accurate even if the original book details in the `/books` collection are changed or deleted. A second denormalization copies the entire order object to a top-level `/orders` collection to facilitate admin querying without compromising user-specific security rules.
